ALDE proposes reassessing participation criteria for non-reformist regimes to safeguard the "more for more" principle, suggesting stricter conditionality for summit-level engagement.

SD strongly upholds the issue's alignment with S&D priorities on democratic reforms and societal resilience, particularly endorsing the "more for more" principle as essential for incentivizing tangible progress in governance and anti-corruption measures.  
SD proposes enhancing the Eastern Partnership’s focus on hybrid threat mitigation by tripling funding for East StratCom to counter Russian disinformation campaigns, while fully endorsing the summit’s conflict issue priorities in Ukraine and Georgia.  
SD applauds the visa liberalization achievements and urges accelerated mobility partnerships, suggesting Erasmus+ quotas be increased by 30% for Eastern Partnership students to strengthen people-to-people ties.  
SD recommends integrating tuberculosis eradication and labor rights initiatives into the 20 deliverables framework, transforming Georgi Pirinski’s concerns into concrete health governance benchmarks for the 2020 work plan.  
SD stresses strict conditionality for financial aid, urging the creation of an independent audit mechanism to prevent oligarchic capture of EU funds, while strongly upholding Joachim Schuster’s call for irreversible reform linkages.

ECR strongly advocates the EAP+ model’s vision for deeper integration into EU frameworks like the Customs Union, aligning perfectly with ECR’s commitment to incentivizing democratic reforms through tangible benefits.  
ECR strongly endorses prioritizing conflict issue mechanisms against Russian aggression, effectively advancing ECR’s security priorities in Ukraine, Georgia, and Moldova.  
ECR strongly advocates shifting to citizen-centered policies, including SME development and a proposed Eastern Partnership University, to build societal resilience and counter hybrid threats.  
ECR strongly approves conditioning EU assistance on verifiable anti-corruption progress and countering disinformation, reflecting ECR’s emphasis on accountability and democratic integrity.  
ECR proposes enhancing the issue’s language to explicitly safeguard minority rights in Ukraine’s education reforms, ensuring compliance with bilateral and international obligations.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's continuation of blank-check financial support to Eastern Partnership governments without binding anti-corruption safeguards, totally disputeing with their anti-oligarchic principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's Russophobic narrative that exacerbates geopolitical tensions, inconsistent with their commitment to peaceful EU-Russia dialogue and regional stability.  
The proposal totally disputes with GUE_NGL's stance by ignoring legitimate popular referendums in contested regions while uncritically endorsing EU-aligned regimes' territorial claims.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to address structural poverty and unemployment, instead prioritizing corporate-friendly economic integration over grassroots social justice reforms.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of energy sovereignty by demanding shutdowns of nuclear facilities like Ostrovets, imposing EU decarbonization models without local consultation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of the Eastern Partnership as a shared commitment between the EU and Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova, and Ukraine to deepen relations based on democracy, rule of law, human rights, gender equality, sustainable development, and good governance. It highlighted progress since the 2009 launch, including Association Agreements and Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) with Georgia, Moldova, and Ukraine, visa-free regimes for these countries, a partnership agreement with Armenia, and ongoing negotiations with Azerbaijan, alongside reforms supported by EU technical and financial aid. The resolution underscored challenges such as deteriorating human rights and democratic backsliding in some partner states, unresolved regional conflicts exacerbated by Russian aggression—notably in Ukraine (Crimea annexation) and Georgia (occupied regions)—and hybrid threats undermining European security. It emphasized the "more for more" principle, linking EU support to partners’ reform commitments, and endorsed a strategic 2020 work plan with 20 deliverables focusing on governance, mobility, economic integration, and connectivity. The Parliament urged enhanced EU engagement in conflict resolution, stronger support for democratic transitions, and prioritized bilateral and regional cooperation to advance political association, economic integration, and societal resilience while respecting partners’ sovereign choices in aligning with EU ambitions.

title: EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement: REPORT on EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement
background: Following the 2015 Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) and subsequent EU sanctions relief, Iran's compliance with nuclear commitments prompted renewed diplomatic engagement. Geopolitical shifts, economic potential, and regional security concerns shaped EU-Iran relations. The Parliament will discuss post-JCPOA EU strategy, balancing economic cooperation, human rights, and regional stability priorities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the issue's prioritization of JCPOA implementation and economic cooperation, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to nuclear non-proliferation and multilateral diplomatic achievements.  
EPP applauds the strengthened human rights provisions addressing executions and minority protections, effectively advancing EPP's priority of embedding fundamental freedoms in EU external action.  
EPP proposes amending paragraph 34 to explicitly condemn Iran's state-sponsored Holocaust denial and calls for Israel's destruction, enhancing consistency with EPP's unwavering security partnership with Israel.  
EPP endorses the demand for FATF compliance and WTO accession requirements, which mirror EPP's manifesto goals for accountable global economic integration.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need for strict conditionality in infrastructure investments to combat corruption, reflecting EPP's governance standards while maintaining trade growth objectives.

EFDD slightly endorses the issue's economic engagement framework but demands removal of Syria policy prescriptions as incompatible with nuanced regional diplomacy.  
EFDD requests revision of multilateral institutional mechanisms, advocating bilateral channels to prevent EU overreach in trust-building timelines.  
EFDD insists on binding amendments condemning Iran's Holocaust denial and juvenile executions (Articles 12-14), rejecting current vague human rights formulations.  
EFDD opposes comprehensive security cooperation clauses, urging sector-specific counterterrorism agreements to avoid legitimizing Iran's regional proxies.  
EFDD requires explicit acknowledgment of Iran-Israel tensions in Section 5, arguing current regional stability analysis lacks strategic balance.

ENF rejects the issue's selective condemnation of Iran's judicial sovereignty while ignoring Saudi Arabia's Yemen intervention and Turkey's policies, fully disapproveing with ENF's anti-interventionist principles.  
ENF opposes the human rights "incantations" targeting Iran as hypocritical given the issue's silence on Qatar and Saudi Arabia, inconsistent with ENF's stance against double standards in diplomacy.  
ENF fully disapproves with the issue's prioritization of FATF alignment and WTO accession demands, which undermine Iran's sovereign economic strategies critical for EU trade growth.  
ENF criticizes the issue's failure to fully challenge U.S. sanctions harming EU businesses, overlooking ENF's insistence on euro-based transactions to bypass dollar dominance.  
ENF disputes the issue's neglect of Iran's counter-narcotics sacrifices (4,000 border deaths) and counter-ISIS role, which align with ENF's regional security priorities.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue’s shift from isolation to dialogue, aligning perfectly with their commitment to multilateral conflict issue and economic diplomacy as tools for human rights progress.  
GREEN_EFA strongly approves the emphasis on environmental cooperation, particularly urging explicit inclusion of joint efforts to reverse the ecological collapse of Urmia Lake in Caspian pollution mitigation plans.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the call for Iran’s FATF compliance and WTO accession, which mirrors their manifesto priorities on combating illicit finance and fostering equitable trade frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on abolishing executions for drug offenses, directly advancing their decades-long campaign against disproportionate punitive systems globally.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening gender equality provisions by specifying EU funding ties to women’s workplace participation metrics, enhancing the issue’s social justice impact.

ALDE rejects the issue's failure to condition economic engagement on verifiable human rights reforms, absolutely disapproveing with our core principles.  
ALDE opposes the inadequate condemnation of Iran's execution of minors and political prisoners, which violates international law and EU values.  
ALDE demands amendments to explicitly denounce Iran’s support for Hezbollah’s terrorism and its destabilizing regional actions.  
ALDE condemns the issue’s silence on institutionalized gender apartheid and persecution of LGBTQ+ individuals in Iran.  
ALDE insists on binding benchmarks for judicial reforms and free elections before normalizing relations, rejecting “business as usual” with a theocratic regime.

SD firmly accepts the issue's strict JCPOA implementation framework, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to multilateral diplomacy as the cornerstone for EU-Iran economic integration and regional security enhancement.  
SD perfectly supports the linkage between sanctions relief and human rights conditionality, particularly the demand to abolish juvenile executions, which directly advances SD's decades-long campaign against capital punishment and gender-based violence.  
SD firmly accepts leveraging Iran's counter-terrorism capabilities against ISIS through structured regional dialogue, aligning with SD's strategic priority to stabilize conflict zones while condemning sectarian proxy interventions in Syria and Yemen.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's environmental cooperation mandate, recognizing joint climate action on Caspian Sea preservation and solar energy development as critical to fulfilling SD's Green Deal external dimension.  
SD firmly accepts academic mobility programs like Erasmus+ with Iran, seeing them as essential to empower civil society actors and institutionalize the issue's judicial reform agenda through grassroots cultural exchange.

ECR rejects the issue's economic engagement framework for legitimizing the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps' dominance in Iran's economy, contravening ECR's anti-terror financing principles.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the omission of Iran's state-sponsored Holocaust denial and calls for Israel's destruction, which violates ECR's commitment to transatlantic solidarity and Middle East security.  
ECR condemns the report's failure to condition trade growth on abolishing juvenile executions and releasing political prisoners, inconsistent with ECR's human rights red lines.  
ECR disputes the issue's characterization of Iran as a regional stabilizer, citing its "schurkengedrag" in Syria/Yemen as irreconcilable with ECR's counterterrorism priorities.  
ECR demands deletion of Caspian Sea cooperation clauses until Iran halts systematic persecution of ethnic Ahwazi Arabs and other minorities.

GUE/NGL supports the issue’s emphasis on upholding the JCPOA as a diplomatic achievement but urges amending Article 9 to explicitly demand unilateral nuclear disarmament by all EU states and pressure on Israel to join the NPT.  
GUE/NGL advises strengthening human rights provisions by inserting concrete accountability mechanisms for Iran’s historical mass executions, including sanctions against officials implicated in the 1988 massacres of political prisoners.  
GUE/NGL proposes revising Clause 14 to categorically oppose extraterritorial U.S. sanctions harming Iranian civilians and EU businesses, demanding their full repeal as a precondition for deeper economic ties.  
GUE/NGL highlights concerns over the issue’s conflation of Hezbollah with Al-Nusra, urging deletion of this equivalence to reflect Hezbollah’s role in Lebanon’s elected government and regional counterterrorism efforts.  
GUE/NGL endorses environmental cooperation on renewable energy but calls for adding binding commitments to transfer solar technology without intellectual property barriers, aligning with climate justice principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) as a key achievement in multilateral diplomacy, emphasizing strict implementation to enhance EU-Iran relations and regional stability. It welcomed economic opportunities post-sanctions, noting Iran’s GDP of $397 billion (2015), potential for quadrupling EU-Iran trade (then $8 billion), and Iran’s need for $1 trillion in infrastructure investment. The resolution urged Iran to combat corruption, align with FATF recommendations, and pursue WTO accession to integrate into the global economy, while highlighting concerns over U.S. sanctions impacting EU businesses and advocating euro-based transactions. Human rights concerns included Iran’s high execution rates (noting 86% of global opium seizures occur there), urging abolition of the death penalty for drug offenses (potentially reducing executions by 80%) and minors, and calling for releases of political prisoners and dual nationals. It stressed gender equality, protection of ethnic and religious minorities, and judicial reforms. Regionally, Iran’s role in countering ISIS and stabilizing Iraq/Syria was acknowledged, alongside calls for de-escalation with Saudi Arabia and regional cooperation on security, energy, and refugee management (noting Iran hosts 3 million Afghans). Environmental cooperation on water scarcity, renewable energy (highlighting Iran’s solar potential), and Caspian Sea pollution was encouraged. Educational exchanges, including Erasmus Mundus and Horizon 2020 collaboration, were promoted to foster people-to-people ties. The resolution balanced economic engagement with demands for human rights progress, advocating a "four Cs" dialogue (comprehensive, cooperative, critical, constructive) to advance mutual interests while addressing systemic challenges.

title: EU-Afghanistan Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, of the other part
background: The EU and Afghanistan signed a Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development in 2017, provisionally applied since December 2017, following years of EU development aid and amidst ongoing security challenges. The Parliament will discuss concluding the agreement, establishing the first legal framework for bilateral relations across governance, development, and regional stability.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the comprehensive framework addressing political-strategic priorities and state-building imperatives, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to fostering stable governance structures in conflict-affected regions.  
EPP approves the integration of human rights safeguards and economic development provisions, effectively advancing EPP's priority of combining rule-of-law initiatives with sustainable growth strategies.  
EPP emphasizes the critical migration management components, proposing enhanced technical assistance to address Afghanistan’s capacity constraints in handling cross-border population movements.  
EPP endorses the sectoral cooperation mechanisms as vital for institutional strengthening, particularly in security and peace-building domains central to EPP’s external action agenda.  
EPP applauds the agreement’s regional actor engagement clauses, which mirror EPP’s 2019 manifesto call for multidimensional partnerships in South Asia.

EFDD partially supports the development framework but requests revisions to prioritize trade liberalization over state-building, citing historical failures of external governance models.  
EFDD fully opposes centralized fund allocation mechanisms, demanding strict auditing protocols to prevent misuse and ensure direct local community benefits.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of regional security dynamics, requiring binding clauses for neighboring states' involvement in stability efforts to avoid EU overextension.  
EFDD rejects the current human rights conditionality as insufficient, insisting on measurable benchmarks for judicial reforms and anti-corruption prosecutions.  
This agreement conflicts with EFDD's principles of minimal state intervention, advocating instead for tariff elimination and private sector-led growth initiatives to drive sustainable development.

ALDE fully approves the agreement's strategic alignment with EU values in promoting rule of law and democratic governance as essential pillars for Afghanistan's stability.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on sustained financial commitments, particularly the €474 million package to reinforce public sector reforms and migration management.  
ALDE highlights the necessity of inclusive peace negotiations involving Afghanistan's government as critical to preserving constitutional rights and preventing security vacuums.  
ALDE emphasizes the agreement's role in safeguarding women's freedoms against regression, ensuring Taliban engagement doesn't compromise two decades of gender equality progress.  
ALDE supports the regional cooperation framework as vital to addressing cross-border challenges while maintaining conditionality on human rights benchmarks.

SD strongly endorses the agreement's emphasis on human rights and governance reforms, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to gender equality and minority protections in conflict issue frameworks.  
SD approves the development partnership while proposing enhanced monitoring mechanisms to ensure women's participation benchmarks are enforced across all peace process stages.  
SD strongly endorses the security cooperation provisions but recommends intensified EU mediation to integrate Afghanistan's neighbors into a regional stability pact, addressing cross-border proxy dynamics.  
SD urges immediate reassessment of Member States' asylum return policies to reflect Afghanistan's deteriorating security situation, aligning with the agreement's humanitarian obligations.  
SD emphasizes the need to triple humanitarian aid allocations within existing frameworks, directly linking disbursements to verifiable progress in peace process inclusivity and civilian protection.

GUE_NGL rejects the agreement’s neoliberal economic framework, which prioritizes foreign corporate profits over Afghan welfare, fully disputeing with their anti-austerity and anti-exploitation principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes the inclusion of migration provisions enabling forced returns to Afghanistan, denouncing this as a violation of refugee rights and international humanitarian law.  
GUE_NGL highlights the agreement’s failure to address documented harms of IMF-imposed structural adjustments, directly contradicting their stance against market-driven development models.  
GUE_NGL condemns the promotion of natural resource extraction by EU firms, which overlooks critical ecological and social justice concerns central to the party’s platform.  
GUE_NGL asserts the issue’s security focus perpetuates militarized interventionism, inconsistent with their commitment to peaceful, sovereignty-respecting cooperation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to conclude the Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development between the European Union, its Member States, and the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, aimed at strengthening bilateral cooperation in areas such as development, governance, human rights, rule of law, migration, and security. The resolution references the legal basis under Articles 207, 209, and 218 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, endorsing the draft Council decision (15093/2016) and the draft agreement (05385/2015). It aligns with the Committee on Foreign Affairs’ recommendation and the Committee on Development’s opinion (A8-0026/2019), emphasizing the agreement’s role in fostering stability and sustainable development in Afghanistan. The Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its approval to the Council, Commission, EU member states’ governments and parliaments, and Afghanistan’s government and parliament, finalizing the procedural steps for the agreement’s adoption.

title: EU-Australia Framework Agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the Union of the Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Australia, of the other part
background: The EU and Australia negotiated a framework agreement to deepen bilateral cooperation across policy areas, requiring European Parliament consent under EU treaty obligations for international agreements. The Parliament will discuss the agreement's compliance with institutional procedures and legal frameworks governing EU external action and member state competencies.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the Framework Agreement, aligning perfectly with their commitment to effective EU legislation and international cooperation as key to addressing global challenges.  
EPP applauds the emphasis on subsidiarity and proportionality, crucial for maintaining citizen trust and countering Eurosceptic narratives.  
EPP approves the agreement's strategic focus on quality legislation and political dialogue, consistent with their priorities for EU-Australia relations.  
EPP proposes enhancing national parliamentary engagement through more flexible timelines for reasoned opinions to strengthen implementation.  
EPP underscores the need to balance subsidiarity with solidarity principles to ensure equitable outcomes across member states.

ENF rejects the Framework Agreement as it undermines subsidiarity by centralizing EU-Australia policy coordination, conflicting with ENF's core principle of safeguarding national sovereignty against supranational overreach.  
ENF opposes the issue’s legal basis in TFEU Articles 207 and 218, which enable expanded EU competence in foreign policy—a mechanism ENF views as eroding member states’ autonomous decision-making capacities.  
The proposal completely condemns with ENF’s demand for a “red card” procedure to empower national parliaments in blocking EU legislation, as it perpetuates top-down integration without meaningful democratic checks.  
ENF condemns the omission of explicit guarantees for national parliaments to issue motivated opinions at all legislative stages, a flaw that disregards ENF’s 2018 manifesto calling for decentralized governance.  
The agreement overlooks critical risks of regulatory alignment with Australia on environmental standards, which ENF argues could bypass stricter national protections upheld by member states under subsidiarity.

SD strongly agrees the Framework Agreement’s alignment with SD’s commitment to multilateralism, sustainable development, and democratic accountability, particularly its emphasis on joint action for environmental protection and economic cooperation.  
SD proposes enhancing corporate social responsibility provisions within the agreement’s economic chapter to address parliamentary demands for ethical business practices, as raised by national legislatures.  
SD applauds the agreement’s reinforcement of subsidiarity principles, which align with SD’s advocacy for EU policies that respect national sovereignty while advancing collective goals.  
SD emphasizes the need to formalize mechanisms for ongoing dialogue with national parliaments, ensuring citizen-centric policymaking as highlighted in the debate on subsidiarity tools.

ECR strongly endorses the agreement's alignment with subsidiarity principles, enhancing democratic legitimacy through structured national parliamentary engagement.  
ECR endorses the framework's strategic value in advancing EU-Australia cooperation on security and economic priorities while respecting member state competencies.  
ECR applauds provisions reinforcing local decision-making autonomy, consistent with their commitment to decentralizing EU-level authority.  
ECR proposes formalizing pre-legislative consultations with national parliaments to strengthen subsidiarity assessments without opposing the agreement's core objectives.  
ECR approves the balanced approach to shared challenges, emphasizing that implementation must prioritize member states' direct accountability to citizens.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to conclude the Framework Agreement between the EU and its Member States and Australia, aimed at enhancing bilateral cooperation across foreign policy, security, economic matters, sustainable development, and environmental protection. The resolution references the draft Council decision (15467/2016) and the draft Framework Agreement (09776/2016), emphasizing alignment with legal bases under Article 37 of the Treaty on European Union and Articles 207, 212(1), and 218 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It underscores the agreement’s role in deepening political dialogue and joint action on global challenges, while instructing the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its position to the EU Council, Commission, and relevant national governments and parliaments, including Australia’s. The Committee on Foreign Affairs’ recommendation (A8-0110/2018) supported the agreement, reflecting its strategic importance for EU-Australia relations.

title: EU-Australia Framework Agreement (Resolution): REPORT containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the Union of the Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Australia, of the other part
background: The EU and Australia share longstanding diplomatic and economic ties, reinforced by multiple bilateral agreements on trade, security, and climate cooperation. Australia's strategic role in the Indo-Pacific and alignment with EU values on governance and international law underpinned efforts to formalize enhanced collaboration. The Parliament will discuss concluding a comprehensive framework agreement to deepen bilateral relations across policy areas.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the issue’s alignment with subsidiarity and proportionality principles, reinforcing the EPP’s commitment to legitimizing EU legislation while empowering national parliaments to enhance democratic accountability.  
EPP approves the emphasis on national parliaments’ role in EU decision-making and proposes enhancing flexibility in the eight-week deadline for submitting reasoned opinions to accommodate diverse parliamentary procedures.  
EPP applauds the integration of climate action and trade reciprocity with Australia, reflecting the EPP’s prioritization of sustainable growth and strategic Indo-Pacific partnerships aligned with shared democratic values.  
EPP underscores the necessity of balancing subsidiarity with solidarity principles in EU-Australia cooperation, ensuring policies address disparities between member states while advancing collective security and climate goals.  
EPP commends the issue’s focus on cybersecurity collaboration and intelligence-sharing via Europol, which aligns with the EPP’s 2023 manifesto pledge to strengthen transcontinental security frameworks.

ENF firmly disapproves the Framework Agreement as a vehicle for deepening EU supranational integration, contradicting their core principle of defending national sovereignty against Brussels-centric policymaking.  
ENF rejects the issue’s failure to mandate a “red card” mechanism allowing national parliaments to block EU initiatives like this agreement that encroach on member states’ exclusive competencies.  
ENF condemns the omission of continuous subsidiarity checks throughout the legislative process, which would safeguard against overreach in areas such as migration cooperation outlined in the issue.  
ENF argues the issue’s emphasis on EU-led security missions (e.g., EUCAP Nestor) disregards the primacy of nation-states in defense matters, violating Protocol No. 2 on subsidiarity.  
ENF highlights that the agreement’s climate and trade provisions centralize regulatory power in EU institutions, undermining Australia’s bilateral engagements with individual member states.

SD strongly upholds the EU-Australia Framework Agreement’s alignment with democratic values and rule of law, particularly its emphasis on reinforcing shared commitments to climate action and human rights, which perfectly aligns with SD’s longstanding commitment to global justice and sustainable development.  
SD applauds the issue’s focus on reciprocity in trade negotiations and protection of environmental standards, proposing to enhance this further by explicitly integrating corporate social responsibility principles into the FTA’s labor provisions to address parliamentary "green card" requests.  
SD commends the issue’s recognition of Australia’s climate leadership and urges accelerated collaboration on renewable energy targets, suggesting a joint EU-Australia innovation fund for clean technology as a concrete enhancement opportunity.  
SD absolutely advocates the emphasis on Indo-Pacific security cooperation and intelligence-sharing through Europol, noting this effectively advances SD’s priority of multilateral counter-terrorism strategies while maintaining proportionality in cross-border data governance.  
SD welcomes the call for improved asylum-seeker conditions as consistent with SD’s human rights agenda, proposing an amendment to include EU technical assistance to Australia for regional processing center reforms without opposing the issue’s core principles.

ECR strongly upholds the issue's emphasis on democratic accountability and subsidiarity principles, aligning perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to decision-making closest to citizens.  
ECR approves the strategic cooperation framework as effectively advancing shared security priorities through Europol intelligence-sharing and Indo-Pacific stability measures.  
ECR proposes strengthening national parliamentary oversight mechanisms in FTA negotiations through structured consultation phases prior to tariff finalization.  
ECR commends the alignment with EU sanctions regimes and counter-terrorism coordination as exemplary models of sovereign states collaborating on global challenges.  
ECR emphasizes the critical need to rigorously apply subsidiarity tests to climate policy implementation mechanisms under the agreement.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of the Framework Agreement (FA) between the EU and Australia, which strengthens bilateral cooperation on foreign policy, security, human rights, climate action, trade, migration, and counter-terrorism. The resolution highlighted shared values like democracy, rule of law, and respect for international law, noting Australia’s role as the EU’s second-largest trading partner in 2016 (19.3% of imports, 10.3% of exports) with significant mutual investments (€117.7 billion EU FDI in Australia and €21.7 billion Australian FDI in the EU in 2015). It welcomed upcoming EU-Australia FTA negotiations, emphasizing reciprocity, protection of sensitive sectors like agriculture, and maintaining environmental and labor standards. The resolution commended Australia’s climate commitments, including reducing emissions by 26-28% below 2005 levels by 2030, doubling renewable energy capacity by 2020, and co-chairing the Green Climate Fund, alongside its ratification of the Paris Agreement. It recognized Australia’s contributions to global security, including counter-terrorism efforts in Southeast Asia, anti-piracy operations, and participation in EU-led missions like EUCAP Nestor, as well as alignment with EU sanctions against Russia over Ukraine. The resolution underscored cooperation on migration through the Bali Process and support for UN Global Compacts on refugees and migration, while urging Australia to address asylum-seeker conditions in Papua New Guinea and Nauru. It praised Australia’s Closing the Gap strategy for Indigenous communities and its election to the UN Human Rights Council (2018–2020). The resolution also emphasized joint efforts in cybersecurity, intelligence-sharing via Europol, and promoting regional stability in the Indo-Pacific, including freedom of navigation in the South China Sea.

title: EU-Canada Strategic Partnership Agreement: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Strategic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Canada, of the other part
background: Negotiated over seven years, the EU-Canada Strategic Partnership Agreement and Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) aim to enhance economic cooperation and shared democratic values amid rising global protectionism and challenges to multilateral trade frameworks. The Parliament will discuss finalizing the agreements to deepen bilateral trade and geopolitical alignment.

stances.stance:
EPP completely advocates the Strategic Partnership Agreement as it perfectly aligns with their commitment to fact-based economic growth, evidenced by the 55% export increase and 14\xa0000 new jobs created through the EU-South Korea agreement.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on rules-based globalization, viewing CETA as essential counterbalance to protectionist trends and a demonstration of EU leadership in shaping international trade standards.  
EPP completely advocates the modernization of dispute issue mechanisms, affirming that CETA's investor courts strengthen legal predictability while maintaining national judicial sovereignty, contrary to opposition claims.  
EPP fully supports the agreement's geostrategic dimension, emphasizing its role in reinforcing transatlantic partnerships with democratic allies against isolationist policies like those of the Trump administration.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the agricultural safeguards and mutual recognition of 143 geographical indications, noting this protects European farmers while expanding market access for SMEs.

EFDD rejects the Strategic Partnership Agreement for instituting undemocratic technocratic bodies that bypass parliamentary oversight, as outlined in Articles 15-17.  
EFDD opposes the agreement’s ISDS mechanisms, which prioritize corporate tribunals over national sovereignty, directly conflicting with EFDD’s constitutional principles.  
EFDD condemns the issue’s failure to address GMO proliferation and hormone-treated meat imports, violating EU food safety standards specified in Annex 4.  
EFDD entirely rejects with the economic clauses, citing irreversible job losses and wage suppression inconsistent with the issue’s social welfare pledges.

ENF rejects fundamentally the issue's claims of shared values, citing CETA's destruction of 200,000 European jobs and irreversible damage to agricultural sectors through unequal competition with Canadian producers.  
ENF opposes the supranational regulatory cooperation mechanisms as unconstitutional power grabs that bypass national sovereignty, directly contradicting Article 4's "enhanced dialogue" framework.  
ENF condemns the investor-state dispute settlement system as corporate-dominated parallel justice, irreconcilable with the issue's stated commitment to "rules-based international order."  
ENF denounces the issue's climate action pretense given CETA's facilitation of hormone-treated meat and GMO imports, violating Europe's precautionary principle and consumer protections.  
ENF declares the agreement a death sentence for small EU businesses like France's footwear industry, exposing them to multinational predation despite the issue's "sustainable development" rhetoric.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue's alignment with multilateral climate governance, proposing strengthened accountability mechanisms for fossil fuel infrastructure projects.  
GREEN_EFA endorses enhanced parliamentary oversight in trade agreements, urging amendment of Article 12 to require real-time negotiation document access for all MEPs.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on human rights protections while recommending explicit bans on corporate lobbyists with former Commission roles from advisory panels.  
GREEN_EFA approves the sustainable development framework but suggests inserting binding renewable energy investment targets in Annex 3-B.  
GREEN_EFA welcomes cross-border labor protections while advocating for amendment of Chapter 23 to criminalize tax avoidance schemes by multinational corporations.

ALDE strongly endorses the agreement's market access provisions for SMEs, aligning with their commitment to job creation and competitive global trade while ensuring maintained environmental and consumer standards.  
ALDE endorses the reformed investment dispute mechanism as a model for future agreements, proposing enhanced transparency reviews during implementation to solidify trust in the system.  
ALDE applauds the geopolitical reinforcement of EU-Canada relations, recognizing its critical timing to counter protectionism and uphold multilateralism per their 2023 manifesto priorities.  
ALDE emphasizes the agreement’s alignment with shared democratic values, particularly its safeguards for public services and climate commitments, advancing rules-based cooperation.  
ALDE highlights CETA’s role in setting a gold standard for future trade deals, notably through intellectual property protections and mutual recognition of professional qualifications.

SD strongly accepts the replacement of ISDS with a public Investment Court System, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to transparent dispute issue free from corporate interference.  
SD approves the explicit protection of public services and workers' rights in CETA, effectively advancing SD's priority of shielding social protections from deregulation pressures.  
SD endorses the agreement's climate action framework with Canada as a strategic counterweight to isolationist policies, reinforcing multilateral governance structures.  
SD proposes enhancing future agreements through binding sanctions for sustainable development violations while maintaining strong support for CETA's current environmental clauses.  
SD applauds improved transparency provisions but suggests formalizing civil society consultation timelines in Annex 12-B to ensure earlier stakeholder input.

ECR strongly endorses the Strategic Partnership Agreement as a catalyst for job creation and expanded market access, particularly benefiting small and medium enterprises through tariff elimination and procurement opportunities.  
ECR approves the agreement’s alignment with free trade principles, emphasizing its role in reducing consumer costs and countering protectionist trends while maintaining environmental and labor standards.  
ECR highlights the modernized Investment Court System as a critical improvement over ISDS, ensuring fair dispute issue without compromising national regulatory sovereignty.  
ECR proposes enhancing future negotiation efficiency to avoid multi-year delays, noting that prolonged timelines risk undermining the EU’s trade policy credibility.  
 Internal dissent on agricultural safeguards and ISDS legacy concerns is acknowledged but does not detract from the group’s consolidated endorsement.

GUE/NGL firmly challenges the agreement's preservation of ISDS mechanisms, which institutionalize corporate privilege over democratic sovereignty and public interest.  
GUE/NGL rejects CETA's negative list approach as a Trojan horse for forced liberalization of public services and SME sectors against citizens' will.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's failure to prohibit tar sands oil imports, directly contradicting climate obligations and enabling ecological devastation.  
GUE/NGL highlights how the regulatory cooperation chapter subverts legislative autonomy, allowing preemptive corporate influence on laws before parliamentary deliberation.  
GUE/NGL asserts the agreement's labor provisions betray workers by ignoring ILO Convention 98 violations in Canada, accelerating social dumping risks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the conclusion of the Strategic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and Canada, aimed at deepening bilateral cooperation across political, economic, and global challenges. The resolution endorsed the agreement, which seeks to enhance dialogue and collaboration in areas such as foreign policy, security, trade, sustainable development, human rights, and justice. It emphasized the importance of shared values and common objectives, including climate action, multilateralism, and the rules-based international order. The Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its position to the Council, the Commission, and the governments and parliaments of EU Member States and Canada, finalizing the ratification process to strengthen EU-Canada relations.

title: China, notably the situation of religious and ethnic minorities: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on China, notably the situation of religious and ethnic minorities
background: China's policies on religious and ethnic minorities, including reports of mass arbitrary detentions, re-education camps in Xinjiang, restrictions on religious practices, and digital surveillance, alongside existing EU-China frameworks like the Strategic Partnership and human rights dialogues, form the context. The Parliament will discuss minority rights and human rights concerns in China.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the issue's focus on systemic religious persecution against Christians, aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to defending freedom of worship globally.  
EPP approves the demand for immediate closure of Xinjiang re-education camps and proposes amending Article 4 to specify targeted sanctions against officials overseeing mass surveillance systems.  
EPP endorses reciprocity principles for regional access and urges enhancing the EU-China human rights dialogue with mandatory progress benchmarks on church reconstructions.  
EPP emphasizes the urgency of protecting Tibetan cultural identity through monitoring mechanisms for forced assimilation practices, as outlined in the issue's preamble.  
EPP proposes adding explicit reference to conditioning EU-China trade agreements on verifiable improvements in Uyghur family reunification efforts.

ENF totally condemns the issue as hypocritical interference, noting Europe’s destructive 19th-century imperialism and imposition of ideologies like Marxism fractured China’s sovereignty.  
ENF rejects moralizing critiques from nations with histories of religious wars and colonialism, asserting Europe lacks standing to lecture China on minority policies.  
ENF argues the issue overlooks China’s state-driven economic revival as a sovereign achievement contradicting Western interventionist models.  
ENF contends the proposal violates the UN Charter’s non-intervention principles, urging adherence to international law over politicized condemnations.  
ENF dismisses selective focus on minority issues while ignoring Europe’s own violent territorial conflicts and ideological impositions.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue’s unequivocal stance against cultural erasure policies, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to protecting self-determination rights for all minority groups.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on documenting forced assimilation practices in Xinjiang and Tibet as a critical step toward international accountability mechanisms.  

GREEN_EFA proposes amending Section 4 to include explicit support for UNESCO-led cultural preservation initiatives targeting endangered Uyghur manuscripts and sacred sites.  

GREEN_EFA endorses leveraging EU-China trade agreements to mandate independent monitoring of vocational training centers, reflecting their manifesto principle of ethical conditionality.  

GREEN_EFA urges expanded parliamentary collaboration with Kazakh and Kyrgyz civil society groups to track transnational family separations caused by detention policies.

ALDE strongly endorses the issue’s urgent focus on Xinjiang’s arbitrary detention camps, aligning perfectly with their commitment to human rights and multilateral accountability, and demands immediate EU coordination with UN mechanisms for independent investigations.  
ALDE approves the condemnation of mass surveillance targeting Uyghurs and proposes amending Clause 4 to explicitly prohibit EU companies from exporting facial recognition or biometric tools used in oppression, ensuring compliance with human rights safeguards.  
ALDE emphasizes that the EU-China strategy must prioritize concrete actions over rhetoric, advocating sanctions against officials overseeing repression and multilateral coordination to suspend China’s UN Human Rights Council membership.  
ALDE endorses linking trade agreements to verifiable improvements in minority rights, reflecting their manifesto principle that economic engagement cannot override fundamental freedoms.  
ALDE urges expanding the issue’s scope to include Hong Kong and Tibet, ensuring consistent scrutiny of all systemic religious persecution under China’s governance.

SD strongly endorses the issue’s focus on systemic religious freedom violations in China, aligning with SD’s commitment to protecting minority rights globally.  
SD endorses the condemnation of high-tech surveillance and repression in Xinjiang, urging enhanced measures to prevent technology misuse in human rights abuses.  
SD applauds the attention to interfaith repression affecting Muslims, Christians, and Buddhists, reflecting SD’s 2023 priorities on religious pluralism.  
SD proposes expanding the issue’s scope to include binding measures against transnational repression tactics employed by authoritarian regimes.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of addressing China’s rights violations to prevent normalization of digital authoritarianism, consistent with EU values promotion.

ECR strongly endorses the issue's focus on Xinjiang and Tibet, aligning perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to defending religious freedom and minority rights against authoritarian repression.  
ECR approves the call for unfettered diplomatic access to re-education camps but proposes enhancing Article 4 to explicitly mandate independent verification of detainee conditions during such visits.  
ECR applauds the linkage of bilateral relations to human rights progress, which effectively advances ECR's priority of ensuring economic cooperation never silences criticism of systemic persecution.  
ECR endorses the issue’s condemnation of Christian persecution, urging EU diplomats to replace "bezduszną neutralność" with active solidarity gestures toward oppressed faith communities.  
ECR emphasizes the imperative to close detention facilities, echoing Mark Demesmaeker’s demand that China halt ideological coercion and release all political prisoners.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the issue's alignment with external interference strategies inconsistent with sovereign equality principles.  
GUE_NGL rejects the instrumentalization of human rights discourse to advance destabilization agendas against China, citing EU complicity in systemic rights violations elsewhere.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s tacit endorsement of U.S.-led confrontation tactics, which contravene UN Charter obligations to respect territorial integrity.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s failure to address EU hypocrisy in partnering with rights-abusing states like Saudi Arabia while targeting China selectively.  
GUE_NGL reaffirms its constitutional commitment to non-interference and multilateral cooperation frameworks, urging deletion of all interventionist clauses.

title: Climate diplomacy: REPORT on climate diplomacy
background: The European Union has historically led global climate initiatives through the Paris Agreement and its Climate Diplomacy Action Plan. Recent geopolitical shifts, including the US withdrawal from Paris, and increasing climate-related security and migration challenges necessitate enhanced multilateral engagement. The Parliament will discuss integrating climate objectives into EU foreign policy frameworks and international cooperation strategies.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue’s multilateral climate action framework, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to global leadership, as emphasized by Francesc Gambús’ warning that "no country can resolve climate change alone" and the existential threats faced by small island states.  
EPP endorses integrating climate diplomacy into all trade agreements but proposes amending Article 6 to explicitly require revisiting existing deals like CETA and Mercosur with binding emissions reduction benchmarks and WTO-enforced penalties for environmental dumping.  
EPP applauds the renewable energy targets and climate finance mechanisms, noting Ireland’s renewed commitment to exceed 2030 goals as exemplifying national alignment with EU priorities, per Seán Kelly’s emphasis on "putting our house in order."  
EPP emphasizes proactive climate migration safeguards, urging bilateral agreements with vulnerable regions to include preemptive resilience funding, echoing Μαρία Σπυράκη’s call for diplomacy addressing "the difference between living, fleeing, or dying."  
EPP approves institutional reinforcement of climate diplomacy through increased DG Climate Action funding, ensuring horizontal coordination across foreign policy bodies as urged by Sirpa Pietikäinen’s demand for "climate criteria in all development agreements."

EFDD partially agrees the issue’s climate migration frameworks but demands explicit condemnation of EU member states’ fossil fuel extraction in Africa, citing Paragraph 12’s climate justice principles.  
EFDD rejects the issue’s assumption of direct causality between climate change and migration, insisting on independent verification of displacement projections before allocating funds under Article 7.  
EFDD opposes expanding the Commission’s role in COP24 negotiations (Clause 9), arguing this centralization contradicts subsidiarity and exacerbates bureaucratic overreach in climate governance.  
EFDD requests deletion of carbon pricing harmonization measures (Clause 21), citing unresolved carbon leakage impacts on EU industries and job losses as evidence of flawed decarbonization strategies.  
EFDD totally disapproves with the issue’s trade agreement integration (Section 5), attributing environmental degradation to EU-led globalization policies that perpetuate fossil fuel dependencies.

ALDE strongly sanctions integrating climate diplomacy across all EU external agreements and multilateral dialogues, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to making the Paris Agreement the foundation of global climate governance.  
ALDE approves strengthening institutional frameworks for climate action through enhanced stakeholder collaboration, effectively advancing ALDE's priority of evidence-based policymaking that integrates scientific expertise and private sector innovation.  
ALDE strongly sanctions conditioning EU trade agreements on strict adherence to Paris Agreement commitments and proposes enhancing enforcement mechanisms to ensure all member states meet emission reduction targets, particularly in energy union partners utilizing fossil fuels.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s emphasis on defining "climate refugees" under UN frameworks, urging immediate multilateral negotiations to address displacement linked to environmental degradation.  
ALDE highlights the critical need to apply climate diplomacy principles uniformly within the EU, ensuring member states’ energy transitions align with Paris goals while supporting vulnerable coastal regions.

SD strongly sanctions integrating climate considerations into all EU external policies and commends the PRIMA project as a model for Horizon Europe, proposing reinforced funding to amplify Mediterranean and North African climate resilience initiatives.  
SD approves the issue’s focus on EU diplomatic leadership, aligning perfectly with S&D’s commitment to multilateral collaboration and global climate governance.  
SD endorses holding major emitters accountable and urges increased EU investments in sustainable technologies to solidify its role as an environmental frontrunner.  
SD advocates strengthening proactive alliances with vulnerable regions and international bodies, emphasizing the need for structured climate diplomacy to enforce the Paris Agreement.  
SD underscores the issue’s alignment with gender equality principles, highlighting the imperative to elevate women’s representation in climate negotiations as a cornerstone of just climate action.

ECR totally conflicts the creation of "climate refugee" frameworks, asserting this would destabilize migration policy and lacks Paris Agreement foundations.  
ECR rejects demands for exceeding Paris Agreement obligations, arguing the issue undermines the accord’s balance by imposing unilateral decarbonization timelines.  
ECR highlights contradictions in advocating global climate finance while EU fails to enforce environmental law internally, citing unresolved illegal wind park cases in Greece.  
ECR disputes net-zero 2050 targets as incompatible with Paris Agreement’s recognition of natural CO2 absorption through forests.  
ECR opposes diverting 30% of EU budget to climate initiatives, prioritizing strict domestic regulatory compliance over aspirational funding pledges.

GUE_NGL partially advocates the issue’s emphasis on EU climate leadership but demands binding mechanisms to hold member states like Ireland accountable for meeting emission targets, as current voluntary measures fail to ensure compliance.  

GUE_NGL opposes the absence of a concrete EU-led initiative to establish an international legal status for climate refugees, which is inconsistent with their demand for immediate recognition and protection frameworks.  

GUE_NGL highlights that the issue’s approach to climate diplomacy overlooks the need to eliminate loopholes in EU climate legislation, directly conflicting with their stance against diluted environmental laws as criticized by Climate Action Network.  

GUE_NGL requests revising Article 12 to mandate gender parity in climate negotiation delegations, noting that the current 12-15% representation of women is fundamentally inadequate and undermines inclusive policy-making.  

GUE_NGL challenges the issue’s reliance on market-based solutions like carbon pricing, advocating instead for systemic changes to phase out fossil fuels without conditional partnerships that risk greenwashing.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the severe impacts of climate change on global stability, human rights, migration, and vulnerable populations, emphasizing its role as a "threat multiplier" exacerbating conflicts, inequality, and displacement. It reaffirmed the EU’s commitment to the Paris Agreement, urging increased ambition to limit global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels, and called for a net-zero carbon strategy by 2050, aligning with enhanced 2030 Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs). The resolution stressed the need for climate diplomacy to integrate mitigation, adaptation, and resilience into EU foreign policy, trade agreements, and security strategies, while addressing climate-induced migration—projected to affect up to 200 million people by 2050—through international legal frameworks for "climate refugees." It highlighted the EU’s role as the largest provider of public climate finance, advocating for 30% of the EU budget to support climate-related initiatives and leveraging partnerships to phase out fossil fuels, promote renewables, and transfer green technologies. Gender equality, indigenous rights, and human rights were underscored as central to climate action, with calls to address women’s underrepresentation (12-15% of delegation heads) in climate negotiations. The EU was urged to lead multilateral efforts, strengthen carbon pricing mechanisms, and collaborate with international bodies like the G20, Arctic Council, and UN agencies, while pressuring sectors like aviation and shipping to reduce emissions. The resolution also emphasized support for vulnerable regions, including small island states and the Arctic, and stressed the importance of local governance, scientific research, and civil society engagement in achieving climate justice and sustainable development.

title: Azerbaijan, notably the case of Mehman Huseynov: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Azerbaijan, notably the case of Mehman Huseynov
background: Azerbaijani blogger Mehman Huseynov was imprisoned in 2017 for criticizing government corruption, with new charges emerging in December 2018 amid reports of restricted press freedom and blocked independent media. Azerbaijan, a Council of Europe member, engaged in EU partnership negotiations since 2016. The Parliament will discuss human rights concerns and media freedom in Azerbaijan within bilateral relations.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves anchoring EU-Azerbaijan relations in democratic reforms and human rights, aligning with their commitment to foundational European values.  
EPP approves the urgent demand for Mehman Huseynov’s unconditional release and medical care, condemning extended sentences for political prisoners as incompatible with rule of law.  
EPP endorses linking the Comprehensive Agreement negotiations to measurable progress on civil liberties, particularly media freedom and judicial independence.  
EPP proposes strengthening scrutiny of Azerbaijan’s 2017 legal amendments to ensure independent legal representation for detainees facing politically motivated charges.  
EPP commends the issue’s focus on systemic corruption and transnational repression tactics, urging EU delegations to prioritize civil society safeguards.

EFDD partly accepts the issue’s condemnation of Azerbaijan’s press freedom violations but requests revisions to impose explicit sanctions on officials overseeing Huseynov’s solitary confinement.  
The proposal overlooks EFDD’s principle that EU negotiations must immediately freeze until Azerbaijan releases Mukhtarli and Mammadov, per Article 12’s insufficient linkage to conditional engagement.  
EFDD finds the issue inconsistent with its demand for direct EU accountability by requiring public audits of Council of Europe members linked to Azerbaijani corruption allegations.  
The civil society funding reforms fail to address EFDD’s priority of mandating unrestricted access for EU delegations to monitor detained activists like Ismayilova in real time.  
EFDD opposes the issue’s reliance on gradual legal reforms, advocating instead for an immediate repeal of laws barring non-Bar Association lawyers through binding EU trade conditionality.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s condemnation of Azerbaijan’s repression against journalists and activists, fully aligning with their commitment to global press freedom and dissent protection.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the demand to release Mehman Huseynov and all political prisoners, urging the EU to suspend Comprehensive Agreement talks until his unconditional freedom is secured.  
GREEN_EFA endorses reforming Azerbaijan’s civil society funding laws and proposes amending the issue to mandate quarterly EU delegation reports on NGO support implementation.  
GREEN_EFA approves linking EU-Azerbaijan relations to human rights compliance, emphasizing this mirrors their 2023 manifesto stance on conditioning trade pacts on judicial transparency.  
GREEN_EFA welcomes the call to investigate Council of Europe corruption allegations, advocating for a dedicated EP committee to review Azerbaijan’s adherence to Strasbourg Court rulings.

ALDE strongly agrees the issue’s demand for the immediate release of Mehman Huseynov and all political prisoners, aligning with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to defending free expression and judicial independence.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need for balanced dialogue with Azerbaijani authorities, proposing enhanced diplomatic channels to replicate past successes like Ilgar Mammadov’s release while maintaining pressure for systemic reforms.  
ALDE approves the linkage of EU-Azerbaijan negotiations to human rights progress, stressing that democratic values must underpin energy partnerships and visa liberalization talks.  
ALDE highlights the importance of rigorous verification of allegations, urging EU delegations to cross-check claims with multiple sources to avoid misinformation risks while advancing accountability.  
ALDE endorses the call to reform restrictive NGO funding laws, noting this aligns with their 2023 priorities to empower civil society through EU technical assistance programs.

SD strongly advocates the issue’s demand for Mehman Huseynov’s immediate release, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to defending freedom of expression and ending political persecution.  
SD approves the call to condition EU-Azerbaijan relations on human rights progress, emphasizing that sanctions against officials responsible for torture and repression must be prioritized to uphold democratic values.  
SD proposes enhancing dialogue mechanisms alongside pressure, such as expanding parliamentary cooperation to reinforce Azerbaijan’s obligations under the European Convention on Human Rights without diluting accountability.  
SD applauds the focus on combating systemic corruption, urging the EU to rigorously investigate alleged bribes to European politicians as outlined in the issue’s anti-corruption demands.  
SD strongly endorses the demand to reform laws restricting civil society funding, noting this aligns with SD’s 2023 manifesto priorities to protect grassroots activism and independent media.

ECR supports the issue’s demands for releasing political prisoners but advises amending Section 4 to explicitly guarantee independent medical assessments and family visitation rights for detainees like Huseynov.  
ECR endorses judicial reform proposals but suggests specifying technical assistance through Eastern Partnership programs to operationalize fair trial guarantees.  
ECR advises strengthening EU-Azerbaijan energy cooperation clauses by linking human rights progress to phased implementation of the Comprehensive Agreement.  
ECR expresses concern over the issue’s minimal recognition of Azerbaijan’s strategic partnership value, proposing an additional paragraph acknowledging bilateral progress while maintaining reform urgency.  
ECR supports conditional engagement but recommends revising Article 9 to include reciprocal trade incentives for demonstrable improvements in press freedom rankings.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Azerbaijan’s systemic human rights violations, focusing on the imprisonment and mistreatment of anti-corruption blogger Mehman Huseynov, who faced additional charges and solitary confinement after a hunger strike, risking a 5-7 year extension to his initial two-year sentence. It highlighted Azerbaijan’s broader crackdown on dissent, citing 10 imprisoned journalists, the blocking of independent media outlets like Azadliq Radio and Meydan TV, and the targeting of activists through arbitrary charges, including the cases of Khadija Ismayilova (fined €23,000 in a disputed tax case) and 15 individuals punished for protesting Huseynov’s treatment. The resolution condemned Azerbaijan’s restrictive legal amendments, such as barring non-Bar Association lawyers from court, undermining defense rights for opposition figures, and noted the country’s poor press freedom ranking (163rd globally). It urged Azerbaijan to release all political prisoners, including journalists and activists like Afgan Mukhtarli and Ilgar Mammadov, comply with European Court of Human Rights rulings (e.g., Ismayilova’s privacy and expression rights violation), and reform laws restricting civil society funding. The Parliament stressed that EU-Azerbaijan relations, including ongoing negotiations for a Comprehensive Agreement, must prioritize democratic reforms, rule of law, and human rights, while calling on the EU to condition engagement on tangible progress. It further demanded an end to harassment of LGBTI communities, investigations into alleged corruption involving Council of Europe members, and enhanced support for civil society through EU delegations.

title: Bangladesh, including child marriages: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Bangladesh, including child marriages
background: Bangladesh has Asia’s highest child marriage rate, with 52% of girls married by 18 and 18% by 15, alongside reported human rights concerns including enforced disappearances and civil society restrictions. The Parliament will discuss child marriage prevalence and legislative measures affecting minors’ rights in Bangladesh.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue’s call to amend the 2017 Child Marriage Restraint Act, aligning perfectly with EPP’s commitment to eradicating statutory violence against minors by closing legal loopholes that enable abuse under “special cases.”  
EPP approves the emphasis on resuming Bangladesh’s National Action Plan with concrete steps, particularly integrating health professionals and child consent into judicial criteria to prevent forced marriages.  
EPP proposes enhancing collaboration with local NGOs to address root causes like poverty and education gaps, amending the 2014 Foreign Donations Act to safeguard civil society’s role in empowering marginalized communities.  
EPP applauds the issue’s linkage between child marriage and systemic gender inequality, urging EU dialogues to prioritize girls’ access to education as a cornerstone of social mobility and rights protection.  
EPP suggests reinforcing internal EU policies to criminalize child marriages within member states, ensuring coherence with the issue’s principles when addressing cases involving migrant communities.

EFDD partially promotes the issue’s condemnation of child marriage legalization but demands amendments to explicitly criminalize all underage unions without "special case" exceptions.  
EFDD requests revisions to impose EU sanctions targeting Bangladesh’s Generalized Scheme of Preferences (GSP) benefits until labor rights violations, including stagnant wages since 2013, are remedied.  
EFDD insists the issue include mandatory independent investigations into enforced disappearances and police abuses, citing systemic repression of strikers and journalists.  
EFDD objects to the lack of binding timelines for Bangladesh to amend the 2017 Child Marriage Restraint Act, urging a 12-month compliance deadline tied to aid conditionality.  
EFDD highlights the omission of psycho-legal support mechanisms for child marriage survivors, requiring specific EU-funded rehabilitation programs in partnership with local NGOs.

ALDE absolutely upholds the issue's condemnation of Bangladesh's 2017 Child Marriage Restraint Act, perfectly aligning with ALDE's commitment to eradicating statutory rape loopholes that enable abusers.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with demands to freeze EU development funds until Bangladesh removes "special case" exceptions legalizing underage marriages, as emphasized in Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea’s intervention.  
ALDE fully supports the issue’s call to resume the National Action Plan with enforceable timelines, reflecting ALDE’s prioritization of accountability in child protection frameworks.  
ALDE unequivocally endorses amending the 2014 Foreign Donations Act to protect NGOs, a measure critical to safeguarding civil society’s role in combating systemic gender inequality.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for independent investigations into violence against journalists, reinforcing ALDE’s principle of press freedom as foundational to democracy.

SD strongly advocates the issue's call to amend the 2017 Child Marriage Restraint Act, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to eliminating statutory rape loopholes and protecting minors from forced marriages.  
SD approves enhanced EU diplomatic pressure through funding mechanisms to ensure Bangladesh revises judicial criteria for marriage exceptions, effectively advancing SD's priority of linking development aid to human rights compliance.  
SD proposes complementing legislative reforms with nationwide education initiatives targeting adolescent empowerment as an enhancement opportunity to address root causes of child marriage.  
SD strongly endorses the demand to resume the National Action Plan with concrete timelines, recognizing this as critical for achieving Sustainable Development Goal 5 on gender equality.  
SD applauds the issue's focus on amending the Foreign Donations Act as matching SD's manifesto pledge to safeguard civil society organizations combating early marriages.

ECR strongly advocates the issue’s condemnation of Bangladesh’s 2017 Child Marriage Restraint Act, aligning with ECR’s commitment to eradicating forced marriages and eliminating legal loopholes that enable statutory rape.  
ECR strongly endorses judicial reforms requiring child consent and health professional oversight, emphasizing the need to integrate explicit educational access mandates to empower girls as a primary prevention strategy.  
ECR strongly approves the demand to resume Bangladesh’s National Action Plan with concrete timelines, urging EU technical support for rural education programs targeting root causes like poverty and gender inequality.  
ECR strongly backs amendments to the Foreign Donations Act, stressing protections for NGOs delivering legal aid and girls’ schooling in high-prevalence regions to strengthen civil society’s role.  
ECR proposes enhancing the issue by mandating independent investigations into Rapid Action Battalion operations, addressing extrajudicial killings documented in recent testimonies to ensure accountability for political violence.

GUE_NGL strongly upholds the issue's focus on ending child marriages in Bangladesh, which aligns perfectly with their longstanding commitment to gender equality and children's rights. They emphasize the urgency of closing legal loopholes in the 2017 Child Marriage Restraint Act to prevent statutory rape and forced unions.  
GUE_NGL applauds the call to protect journalists and civil society from violence and censorship, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for press freedom and democratic accountability in EU-Bangladesh partnerships.  
GUE_NGL proposes enhancing judicial oversight in underage marriage exceptions by mandating child consent verification through independent health professionals, ensuring compliance with international conventions.  
GUE_NGL endorses amending the Foreign Donations Act to safeguard NGOs addressing poverty and education gaps, key drivers of child marriages, as outlined in the National Action Plan revival.  
GUE_NGL urges stricter EU monitoring of Bangladesh's human rights obligations, particularly regarding enforced disappearances and SDG targets, to align development aid with tangible democratic reforms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent human rights violations in Bangladesh, including enforced disappearances, attacks on civil society, and violence against political activists and journalists. It highlighted Bangladesh’s alarmingly high child marriage rates, with 52% of girls married by 18 and 18% by 15, ranking it the highest in Asia, and condemned the 2017 Child Marriage Restraint Act for legalizing underage marriages through vague exceptions like “special cases” without requiring child consent, risking increased abuse, statutory rape, and forced marriages to perpetrators. While acknowledging Bangladesh’s legislative efforts and its 2015-2021 National Action Plan to eliminate child marriage, the resolution criticized poor implementation and regression caused by the 2017 law, undermining the government’s own targets to reduce under-15 marriages by 2021 and under-18 marriages by 2041. It urged amendments to close legal loopholes, establish clear judicial criteria involving health professionals and child consent, and resume the National Action Plan with concrete steps. The Parliament also called for gender equality measures, addressing root causes like poverty and lack of education, amending the 2014 Foreign Donations Act to protect NGOs, and ending violence against journalists through independent investigations. It urged the EU to prioritize these issues in dialogues and support Bangladesh’s compliance with international human rights obligations, including the Sustainable Development Goals and conventions on women’s and children’s rights.

title: Building EU capacity on conflict prevention and mediation: REPORT on building EU capacity on conflict prevention and mediation
background: The EU’s evolving role in global peace initiatives, existing multilateral frameworks, and rising security challenges prompted institutional efforts to address gaps in conflict prevention and mediation capacities, leveraging external assistance instruments and strategic partnerships. The Parliament will discuss strengthening EU capabilities in conflict prevention and mediation amid complex global security dynamics.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the proposed institutional restructuring through dedicated Council working groups, viewing it as bureaucratic duplication conflicting with existing external action mechanisms.  
EPP opposes fundamentally the mandatory gender-sensitive conflict analysis requirements, arguing they impose ideological frameworks over situational pragmatism in crisis zones.  
The issue's emphasis on transitional justice mechanisms overlooks critical EPP priorities for immediate security stabilization and counter-terrorism cooperation.  
EPP disputes the budget reallocations for peacebuilding as financially irresponsible, contradicting fiscal discipline principles amid competing cohesion policy needs.  
 While individual EPP members cite successful mediation practices, the group rejects systemic operationalization of these ad-hoc efforts through permanent structures.

SD absolutely accepts the issue’s integration of UNSCR 1325, perfectly aligning with their commitment to centering women’s leadership in peace processes as highlighted by Julie Ward’s emphasis on direct involvement of women from all backgrounds.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s prioritization of civil society partnerships, recognizing their critical role in operationalizing gender-sensitive mediation frameworks as championed in the debate.  
SD applauds the dedicated funding for gender-sensitive conflict analysis, directly advancing their manifesto pledge to eradicate structural drivers of gender-based violence through early warning systems.  
SD fully supports the human security principles outlined, which codify their decades-long advocacy for protecting women and children from conflict-related exploitation as stressed by Julie Ward.  
SD endorses the holistic linkage of mediation and education on gender equality, mirroring their insistence on combining policy tools with grassroots awareness-raising for transformative peacebuilding.

ECR strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on conflict prevention rooted in international law and UN principles, aligning perfectly with ECR’s longstanding commitment to multilateralism and peaceful dispute issue.  
ECR applauds the focus on parliamentary diplomacy through initiatives like the Jean Monnet Dialogue, which effectively advances ECR’s priority of fostering consensus-driven solutions through institutional engagement.  
ECR approves the human-centric approach to addressing root causes of conflict, reinforcing ECR’s principles of sovereignty and non-interference while promoting stability.  
ECR proposes enhancing clarity on safeguarding the non-intervention principle in member states’ internal affairs to ensure alignment with Article 2(7) of the UN Charter.  
ECR endorses expanded partnerships with the OSCE and UN as consistent with its advocacy for rule-based multilateral frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the imperative for the EU to prioritize conflict prevention, mediation, and peacebuilding as central pillars of its external action, emphasizing their alignment with international law, the UN Charter, and Sustainable Development Goals, particularly Goal 16 on peaceful societies. It underscored the EU’s role as a leading global actor in these areas, leveraging its diplomatic, development, and security tools, and called for enhanced institutional coordination, including the establishment of an EU high-level advisory board on conflict prevention chaired by a new EU Special Envoy for Peace, dedicated Council working groups, and task forces for specific conflicts. The resolution stressed the need for gender-sensitive and youth-inclusive approaches, integrating UN Security Council Resolutions 1325 (Women, Peace and Security) and 2250 (Youth, Peace and Security), and highlighted the importance of civil society, local actors, and transitional justice in addressing root causes of conflict. It welcomed initiatives like the Jean Monnet Dialogue for fostering parliamentary consensus in Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia, and the Western Balkans, and urged increased funding under the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework for conflict prevention, mediation support, and peacebuilding, including dedicated budget lines for early warning systems and gender-sensitive conflict analysis. The Parliament also advocated for stronger interinstitutional cooperation, capacity-building for staff and mediators, and expanded partnerships with the OSCE and UN, while emphasizing the EU’s responsibility to protect civilians, particularly women and children, from conflict-related violence and exploitation, and to ensure conflict-sensitive interventions in line with human security principles.

title: EU guidelines and the mandate of the EU Special Envoy on the promotion of freedom of religion or belief outside the EU: REPORT on EU Guidelines and the mandate of the EU Special Envoy on the promotion of freedom of religion or belief outside the EU
background: Rising global violations of freedom of religion or belief, including persecution of religious minorities and discriminatory legislation, alongside the EU’s 2013 guidelines and 2016 Special Envoy appointment, prompted review. The Parliament will discuss strengthening EU external policies on FoRB promotion, institutional mandates, and implementation mechanisms.

stances.stance:
